text_snippet: The morning light through a cracked window frame, where dust dances in sunbeams above a single wilting plant.
The smell of burnt plastic from a leaky pipe that can't be fixed. The landlord won't answer calls.
A child doing homework by candlelight, trying to finish before the power company shuts it off again.
Staring into an empty refrigerator, calculating which bill can wait another week.
Sunday service where everyone brings what they can, and somehow there's enough for all.
Waiting for the last bus at midnight after the second job, feet aching, mind racing about tomorrow.
A stack of medical bills hidden under a magazine, pretending they don't exist for one more day.
Grandmother's hands, worn from decades of work, teaching a child to read from a tattered library book.
The phone screen cracked, but still showing job applications sent into the void.
The dignity of choosing between two cans when the food pantry only allows one per person.
Explaining to a child why they can't go on the school field trip, watching their hope fade.
Kneeling by the bed, praying for strength to face another day of impossible choices.
Knocking on a neighbor's door at 2am, asking if they have a spare can of formula for the baby.
The quiet corner of the public library, where a teenager studies for the GED test while others sleep nearby.
The final notice from the utility company, written in language designed to intimidate and confuse.
The church basement where people gather not just for food, but for the warmth of human connection.
Wearing shoes with holes, calculating how many more miles they can last before completely falling apart.
A mother's forced smile, hiding the exhaustion of working three jobs to keep the lights on.
Sitting alone in a park, feeling the weight of isolation even in a crowd of people.
Tending a community garden plot, finding purpose in nurturing something that grows.
Dressing in the best clothes you have, knowing they're still not quite right for the interview.
An elder sharing stories of survival, passing down wisdom that schools never teach.
Filling out government assistance forms, each question feeling like an invasion of privacy.
Watching children play in a parking lot because there's no safe park nearby, and no car to drive to one.
The surreal world of the night shift, where time loses meaning and days blur together.
A graduation photo on the wall, the only family member to finish college, surrounded by pride and expectation.
The car breaks down again, and with it, the ability to get to work, to the grocery store, to anywhere.
A birthday cake made from scratch because store-bought is too expensive, but love makes it perfect.
The eviction notice taped to the door, the fear of homelessness becoming real.
Using the library's free computer to apply for jobs, racing against the 30-minute time limit.
Watching the sunset from a rooftop, finding moments of beauty despite the struggle below.
